intro: Pseudochimarrhis turbinata, commonly known as the turbinated pseudochimarrhis, is a flowering plant native to Australia. It belongs to the Myrtaceae family and is characterized by its distinctive, turbinated (spiral-shaped) fruits. The plant typically grows in coastal and sandy soils, often in heathland or woodland habitats. Its leaves are lanceolate and covered in a fine, whitish pubescence, while its flowers are small and white or pale pink. The species is of interest to botanists due to its unique morphology and ecological adaptations.
